concept.title: Building DITA output with Ant
concept.shortdesc: You can use the Ant build tool to automate builds that use the DITA processes including output for the sample documents provided with DITA.

conbody.p: DITA provides a set of XSLT scripts for producing help output in Eclipse, Java Help, HTML Help, for producing web HTML pages, or for producing PDF. To make it easier to invoke these scripts, the DITA distribution now provides an experimental Ant file that you can use to build the DITA documentation, demos, and samples.
Ant is a Java-based, Open Source tool provided by the Apache Foundation to declare a sequence of build actions. As such, Ant is well suited for document builds as well as development builds.
You don't have to set up a build environment, of course to run the DITA XSLT scripts. To execute the DITA scripts directly, see the DITA Readme document.
conbody.note: The following instructions and the associated build.xml and ditatargets.xml files are for the Java 1.4.2, Ant 1.6.2, FOP 0.20.5, and Saxon 6.5.3 releases. These instructions are likely to need some adjustment for other versions of these components and for specific environments.

task.title: Setting Up Ant
task.shortdesc: To create an Ant build environment for DITA, you can download and install some Java Open Source components.

taskbody.context: For components other than the JDK, configuring the environment and using the component are often easier if you install the component in a directory without spaces in the pathname.

step.cmd: Download and install a JDK (Java Development Kit).
step.info: Ant requires a full Java development environment (available at http://java.sun.com/j2se/index.jsp).

step.cmd: Download and install the DITA distribution.
step.info: Unzip the DITA distribution in a directory.
You can get the Ant binary distribution from http://ant.apache.org/bindownload.cgi. Follow the instructions for installing Ant in the Ant manual at http://ant.apache.org/manual/index.html.
Saxon is an advanced XSLT processor that integrates well with Ant. You can get Saxon from http://saxon.sourceforge.net/.
FOP is an XSL-FO processor, which you'll need if you want to generate PDF output. You can get a binary distribution of FOP from http://xml.apache.org/fop/download.html.

As of this writing, if you use all of the optional components and follow all of the recommendations in the component documentation, you would end up with the following environment variables:
JAVA_HOME Set to the base directory for the JDK.
ANT_HOME Set to the base directory for Ant.
PATH Includes the add the bin and jre\bin directories under the JDK and the bin directory under Ant.
CLASSPATH For Saxon, includes the saxon.jar library from the Saxon directory. For FOP, includes the fop.jar file from the build subdirectory and the avalon-framework-cvs-20020806.jar and batik.jar files from the lib subdirectory. In principle, you should not have to add JDK or Ant jar files to the CLASSPATH, but if you run into problems, you might want to try that.

conbody.p: After you set up your Ant environment, you can build the DITA output. Merely change to the DITA 1.3 distribution directory and execute Ant on the DITA build.xml file.
The build creates an out directory and puts the build output in subdirectories that parallel the source directory.

To experiment with DITA, you can modify the DITA sample files and then rebuild that portion of the output. First, you remove that portion of the output by specifying a "clean" target. For instance, to rebuild just the FAQ demo, you can execute
To find out the complete list of targets you can clean and build, look at the name attributes for the target elements within the build.xml file. Or, just enter
If you want to build your input to output in an default and easy way, you can try to invoke the prompt mode ant by executing
Ant will prompt you for the input and output. You need to fill in the input file and output directory in correctly upper or lower case.

You can reuse the targets provided by the conductor.xml file in builds for your own DITA content. Just copy the build.xml, conductor.xml, pretargets.xml,ditatargets.xml andcatalog-ant.xml file into a new directory and edit the build.xml to specify your DITA files.
conbody.note: To troubleshoot problems in setting up Java, Ant, Saxon, or FOP, you will get better information from the communities for those components than for the DITA community. Of course, if you find issues with the DITA XSLT scripts (or have ideas for improving them), you should engage the DITA community.

section.title: Ant tasks and scripts

p.draft-comment: here, describe the available Ant tasks and the extra scripts that Erik provided.

section.p: The build process including pre-process can be invoked by using Ant script. There are four major Ant script files, conductor.xml, pretargets.xml, ditatargets.xml and catalog-ant.xml.

dlentry.dd: The main Ant script file which include the other three ant scripts and provides main targets for every output style.

dd.p: The following targets in conductor.xml will invoke the complete processing of dita files which can be called by users.

dlentry.dd:
Transform dita topic or dita map into docbook output. Parameter Table of dita2docbook
Parameter Description Required
args.input The file path and file name of the input file. This argument should be in the same upper or lower case with the filename on file system. Yes
output.dir The path of the output directory. Yes

Transform dita topic or dita map into eclipse help plugin based on xhtml. Parameter Table of dita2eclipsehelp
Parameter Description Required
args.input The file path and file name of the input file. This argument should be in the same upper or lower case with the filename on file system. Yes
output.dir The path of the output directory. Yes
args.eclipse.toc The root file name of the output toc file.(Default is 'toc') No
args.eclipse.plugin The file path of the plugin.xml file for eclipse help (Default value is resource/plugin.xml) No
dita.input.valfile The file name containing filter/flagging/revision information. No
args.css User's CSS filename parameter.
This can be the name of a stylesheet used by one or more topics within an overall group. This stylesheet can use the CSS cascade effect to modify existing properties or it can override or define new properties. No
args.csspath Default CSS path parameter.
This specifies a path for the cascading style sheet (CSS). This allows you to place the CSS in one place and have several different topics point to it. If no CSSPATH is specified, the CSS is assumed to be in the same directory as the XHTML. No
args.hdf The file name containing XHTML to be placed in the HEAD area No
args.hdr The file name containing XHTML to be placed in the BODY running-heading area No
args.ftr The file name containing XHTML to be placed in the BODY running-footing area No
args.draft Default "hide draft & cleanup content" processing parameter (no= hide them); no and yes are valid values; non-yes is ignored. No
args.artlbl Default "output artwork filenames" processing parameter; noand yesare valid values; non-yes is ignored. No

Transform dita topic or dita map into html help output based on html. Parameter Table of dita2htmlhelp
Parameter Description Required
args.input The file path and file name of the input file. This argument should be in the same upper or lower case with the filename on file system. Yes
output.dir The path of the output directory. Yes
dita.input.valfile The file name containing filter/flagging/revision information. No
args.css User's CSS filename parameter.
This can be the name of a stylesheet used by one or more topics within an overall group. This stylesheet can use the CSS cascade effect to modify existing properties or it can override or define new properties. No
args.csspath Default CSS path parameter.
This specifies a path for the cascading style sheet (CSS). This allows you to place the CSS in one place and have several different topics point to it. If no CSSPATH is specified, the CSS is assumed to be in the same directory as the XHTML. No
args.hdf The file name containing XHTML to be placed in the HEAD area No
args.hdr The file name containing XHTML to be placed in the BODY running-heading area No
args.ftr The file name containing XHTML to be placed in the BODY running-footing area No
args.draft Default "hide draft & cleanup content" processing parameter (no= hide them); no and yes are valid values; non-yes is ignored. No
args.artlbl Default "output artwork filenames" processing parameter; noand yesare valid values; non-yes is ignored. No

Transform dita topic or dita map into pdf. Parameter Table of dita2pdf
Parameter Description Required
args.input The file path and file name of the input file. This argument should be in the same upper or lower case with the filename on file system. Yes
output.dir The path of the output directory. Yes
The Ant script file which contains all targets for pre-process.
The Ant script file which contains all targets for main transformation.
The xml catalog information which is used by Ant.

conbody.section:
Sample ant script
These ant scripts are in /ant directory. They are simple and easy to learn. From these files, you can see how to write your own ant script to build your own process.
Here is a sample template for writing an ant script that excute transformation to xhtml in /ant directory
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>
<project name="sample_xhtml" default="all" basedir="..">
<import file="${basedir}${file.separator}conductor.xml"/> <property name="dita.extname" value=".xml"/> <target name="all" depends="sample2xhtml"> </target> <!-- revise below here -->
<target name="sample2xhtml" depends="use-init"> <antcall target="dita2xhtml"> <param name="args.input" value="@DITA.INPUT@"/> <param name="output.dir" value="@OUTPUT.DIR@"/> </antcall> </target> </project>
After you write the input file and output directory to overwrite @DITA.INPUT@ and @OUTPUT.DIR@, the script can do the transformation from your input to xhtml for you by command. As to the property dita.extname, it's a global variable with which you can set the file extension name of the topic file. By default dita.extname is .xml. You can also set it to .dita according to OASIS DITA recommendation.c:\pkg\DITA-OT1.0>ant -f ant/template_xhtml.xml All of targets we use here are defined in conductor.xml. Therefore, you need to import that file before calling the target.
